summary.seg: The manuscript contains a treatise on music theory from the 2nd century CE, Ptolemy's Harmonics . Ptolemy wrote fundamental works in the field of astronomy (the Almagest), geography and astrology; his treatise on harmonics was influential also for scholars in Byzantium and beyond. Harmonics is the science of harmony, combining music, philosophy and mathematics.

This volume was part of the collection of the English classical scholar Thomas Gale (c. 1635-1702), who had it copied around the middle of the 17th century from Oxford, St. John's College, MS 30 ( I. Düring [ed.], Die Harmonielehre des Klaudios Ptolemaios (Göteborg, 1930), pp. XI, LIX; the codex is indicated as Codex Coll. Trinitatis Cantabrigiensis I; see also History). Gale lent the manuscript to John Wallis, who used it for the first printed edition of the text in 1682.

msItem.author: Ptolemy
msItem.title: Harmonics
msItem.note: The text is accompanied by diagrams; between lines and in the margins the scribe wrote extensive scholia (see Mathiesen 1988, p. 291, and I. Düring, Die Harmonielehre des Klaudios Ptolemaios (Göteborg, 1930), pp. xcviii-c)

msItem.title: Book 1
msItem.incipit: f. 1v Περὶ τῶν ἐν ἁρμονικῆ κριτηρίων. Ἁρμονικὴ μέν ἐστι, δύναμις καταληπτική
msItem.note: The text is preceded by a table of contents on f. 1r

msItem.title: Book 2
msItem.incipit: f. 21v Πῶς ἂν καὶ διὰ τῆς αἰσθήσεως ληφθεῖεν οἱ τῶν συνήθων γενῶν λόγοι
msItem.finalRubric: f. 40v Τέλος τοῦ δευτέρου τῶν τοῦ Πτολεμαίου ἁρμονικῶν
msItem.note: The text is preceded by a table of contents on f. 21r; ff. 41r-43v are occupied by diagrams

msItem.title: Book 3
msItem.incipit: f. 46r Πῶς ἂν ἡ δι’ ὅλου χρῆσις τε καὶ ἀνάκρισις γίνοιτο τῶν λόγων διὰ πεντεκαιδεκαχόρδου κανόνος
msItem.explicit: f. 60r l. 17 καὶ διὰ πάντας ἐπισφαλεῖς.
msItem.note: The text is preceded by a table of contents on f. 45r
On f. 60r the scribe wrote in red ink Ἰδοῦ τὸ τέλος τοῦ βιβλίου

There is a lacuna in the text between f. 56v l. 14 and f. 57r, αἱ τῶν παρακειμένων ἀριθμῶν ἐν τῇ καταγραφῇ διαφοραί Ὅτι τῇ κατὰ μῆκος κινήσει τῶν ἀστέρων ( I. Düring, Die Harmonielehre des Klaudios Ptolemaios (Göteborg, 1930), pp. 103 l. 4-104 l. 17); after f. 56 l. 17, the scribe crossed out with a line the rest of the text on the page (it is the beginning of the last chapter of book 3) and traced an asterisk, which recalls the missing text, copied by him on ff. 60r l. 18-60v

msItem.title: Book 3, fragment
msItem.note: After the end of the text of Book 3 (f. 60r l. 18), the scribe wrote a passage of Book 3, chapter 9 which fills the lacuna between f. 56v l. 14 and f. 57r (it is I. Düring, Die Harmonielehre des Klaudios Ptolemaios (Göteborg, 1930), p. 103 l. 5-104 l. 17), indicating in the margin that the passage should be placed previously, as shown by the asterisk, which recalls the place of the lacuna on f. 56v

support.material:
Western paper, folded in folio. Watermarks: ff. [i]-[iii], [vi]-[viii] Grapes with a leaf, under the grapes letters MDP ( 57 35 ), in the centre of the leaf, no exact parallels found in the main repertoires.
ff. 1-6 Coat of arms surmounted by a quatrefoil, under it name A DVRAND
( 100 63 ), in the centre of the leaf, similar to Heawood Coat of arms 655 , which is dated to 1677 (London), and 661 (NP).
ff. 7-60, [iv]-[v] Lily on a cartouche, under the cartouche 4WR, countermark IHS, under these letters IP surmounted by a Latin cross ( 140 70 ), in the centre of leaf, similar to Heawood Lily 1785 and 1785a , which are dated to 1670.

foliation.p: Modern foliation in pencil, in Arabic numerals, in the upper margin right, from 1 to 60; three blank leaves at the beginning and five at the end of the manuscript are unnumbered: [i]-[iii] + 1-60, [iv]-[v] + [vi]-[viii].

collation.p: The quires have been sewn very tightly, the binding is in bad condition, there is no numbering of the quires, therefore it is not possible to ascertain with certainty the original collation.

supportDesc.condition: The manuscript is in fair condition. The left pastedown is almost completely detached from the text block; f. [iii] is detached. The leaves' edges are brittle and flickering. There are tears on various leaves, see e.g. ff. [iv]-[v]. The leaves are yellowed and there are yellow and brown stains throughout.

layoutDesc.layout:
A single column of 38 lines. Text lines are sometimes traced in brown ink (see e.g. f. 49r).
230 145

handNote.p: ff. 1r-13v, 16r-21r, 27r-29v Hand A: the text has been written in a minuscule script, quite regular in size, probably by a western European hand. The script can be dated in the 17th c.
The text is written in brown ink; titles and initials in red.

decoDesc.decoNote: On ff. 1r, 1v, 21r, 21v, 45r, 46r there are undulated linear friezes in red ink with clovers at both ends.
Initials in ekthesis in red ink decorated with a vegetal motif, see e.g. f. 1v,
The text is accompanied by diagrams.

additions.p: On f. [i] recto are written an ancient mark, A.13, and a title, Πτολεμαίου Ἁρμονική.

binding.p: Modern western full reversed skin binding, pasteboards. Blind tooling on covers. On the spine are glued three paper labels with the shelfmark. 382 245 20
binding.condition: The binding is damaged on the spine, the book block is exposed, and the left board is detached.

origin.p: The manuscript was owned by the English classical scholar and antiquarian Thomas Gale (ca. 1635-1702) Gale, Thomas, 1635?-1702 and was copied around the middle of the 17th century in England, from Oxford, St. John's College, MS 30. The manuscript was copied before 1682: it was lent from Gale to John Wallis, who published the first printed edition of the text in that year, and, in the introduction of the volume, wrote that the manuscript (G in his edition) had been copied from Oxford, St. John's College, MS 30 (I in his edition) a few years earlier ( qui fuerat, uti intellego, ex I (codice Johannensi) ante non multos annos descriptus). The date is confirmed by the watermarks.

history.acquisition:
It was donated by Roger Gale (1672-1744) Gale, Roger, 1672-1744
in 1738. On f. [ii] verso is pasted the Trinity College bookplate. Stamps of Trinity College Library are present on ff. 2r, 78v and 79r.

recordHist.source: Description (2020) partly draws on M.R. James, The Western Manuscripts in the Library of Trinity College Cambridge (Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1902), vol. 3, p. 318 and T.J. Mathiesen, Ancient Greek music theory: a catalogue raisonné of manuscripts (München, 1988), pp. 290-292, no. 118

availability.p: Visitors to Trinity College who wish to consult Special Collections material are required to apply to the Library in advance of their visit. For information on eligibility and admission procedures see: Trinity College: Information for Readers.

monogr.title: Klaudiou Ptolemaiou Harmonikōn biblia 3. Claudii Ptolemæi Harmonicorum libri tres: Ex codd. MSS. undecim, nunc primum Græce editus / Johannes Wallis, SS. Th. D. Geometriæ Professor Savilianus Oxoniæ, Regiæ Societatis Londini Sodalis, Regiæque Majestati à Sacris; recensuit, edidit, versione et notis illustravit, et auctarium adjecit.
The western manuscripts in the library of Trinity College: a descriptive catalogue
Ancient Greek music theory: a catalogue raisonné of manuscripts

series.title: International inventory of musical sources. B
